subject: Re: [junit] Test Everything, No Matter How Simple
msgSnippet: ... Elliotte, I don t understand this article. You say that there was a bug in this code: private void _setType(Type type) { this.type = type; } This bug
messageBody:
Elliotte Harold wrote:

> FWIW, here's another small case study where testing first prevented a
> problem in code that was "too simple to fail":
>
> http://cafe.elharo.com/java/test-everything-no-matter-how-simple/
> <http://cafe.elharo.com/java/test-everything-no-matter-how-simple/>

Elliotte, I don't understand this article.

You say that there was a bug in this code:

private void _setType(Type type) {
this.type = type;
}

This bug caused a NullPointerException to occur. I don't see how that's
possible, since "this" cannot be null. I read on. I found out that the
bug is that some other code in this class assumes that this.type is not
null, and because someone was permitted to invoke _setType(null), there
is a problem.

I disagree.

The bug is in whatever code invoked _setType(null). Possibly, the real
bug is in providing a way to change this property after object creation
in the first place.

I strongly doubt the programming error was not testing the setter; it
was not testing the code that tried to use it.

If we /do/ want to make the property writable and publish that API for
anyone to use, then it might be worth programming more defensively, but
in this case, the property isn't even directly writable, which makes me
believe even more strongly that the bug is not in the setter. After
reading your article more closely, the bug was in the non-trivial public
setType() method and not in the private and trivial _setType() method. A
method like setType() that does data checks is certainly not Too Simple
to Break and I would definitely test it.

Based on that, I feel your argument is of the bait-and-switch kind: you
offer up the _setType() example as code that should be tested, but
justify it by concluding that setType() is the method really ought to be
tested. This might be harsh, but that reasoning just doesn't work.

Of course, this is just one man's opinion, and I'm writing this more for
the audience than in any hope of changing your mind. I'm OK with the
fact that we have different thresholds for "Too Simple to Break". I'm
not OK with faulty reasoning.

Take care.
